Lenna,  unfortunately rtNEAT source code has not yet been released
for a variety of reasons.  One is that the version in NERO is tied in
with Torque (the game engine used in NERO) and so would not function 
outside Torque.  

Another reason is that we need to draw up a research license for it 
before it is released since rtNEAT is currently patent pending (it
has been submitted to the US patent office).  It is important to note
that the rtNEAT patent will NOT stop research use, and we intend to
support and allow its use for research purposes.  However, for-
profit commercial use will require a license from the University of 
Texas at Austin, or from anyone who has been granted the right to 
sublicense rtNEAT.  So we need to draw up a research license 
(meaning a license that grants unrestricted rights to use the method 
for research purposes only), which will take a little while, but we 
intend to do it.

In any case, you are certainly free to implement rtNEAT yourself and 
play with it.  Note that the patent will cover any version of rtNEAT,
so you will not be able to profit commercially without paying 
royalties (i.e. you would need a commercial license); HOWEVER no one 
will stop you from performing any kind of not-for-profit research
with it that you want, and research purposes are unrestricted.  
Please let me know if you have questions.

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "paeris20" <dwl01@h...> wrote:
> Greetings,
> 
> 
> I was reading the paper on NERO and hoping to try some of the
methods
> they discussed on a project I've been working on for a while. But I
> wanted to ask if rtNEAT was availible somewhere or if I'll have to
> modify NEAT to work in rt on my own.
> 
> Cheers,
> -Lenna
